awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Dynamic State Transitions in Vehicular Traffic and the Effects of Driver Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award is to investigate the effects of driver behaviors, such as car-following and lane-changing, on traffic state transitions (i.e., changes in traffic conditions such as speed). This research focuses on transitions near freeway choke points (i.e., bottlenecks), merges, and ends of queues (where vehicles encounter congestion). Transitions around these regions can lead to disorderly traffic conditions, such as stop-and-go driving, due to sharp changes in speed and frequent lane-changing maneuvers. This research consists of four primary tasks of (i) collecting new individual vehicle data, (ii) analyzing general features (e.g. changes in traffic flow, density, and speed) of traffic transitions, (iii) analyzing driver behaviors and linking them to the general features, and (iv) extending/developing models of driver behaviors capable of reproducing the observed transition phenomena.

If successful, this research will uncover the physical mechanisms of transitions; i.e., how individual driver behaviors (e.g., car-following, lane-changing) govern changes in flow, density, and speed in time and space.  Understanding these mechanisms has important implications for mobility and safety. Transitions around freeway bottlenecks can determine bottleneck throughput and hence the delays on freeway networks. Further, vehicles in transition regions are more prone to crashes due to sudden changes in speed and frequent lane-changing maneuvers. Therefore, the results from this research will potentially advance traffic control strategies to manage congestion more effectively and improve safety. Educational and outreach activities involve the development of a project website, a smart-phone application to collect probe data, web-based modules for hands-on learning of data analysis methods and modeling. Using these means, this project will engage undergraduate and graduate students, STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) high school teachers to reach out to high-school students in the long term, researchers in other disciplines, and industry stakeholders.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award was to investigate the effects of driver behaviors, such as car-following and lane-changing, on dynamic traffic features. This research investigated transitions near freeway choke points (i.e., bottlenecks) formed by merges, diverges, or weave sections. When demand is sufficiently high, traffic around these regions can quickly transition to disorderly traffic conditions marked by ‘capacity drop’ (reduction in throughput) and stop-and-go driving. This research focused on understanding the physical mechanisms of traffic transitions into such phenomena; i.e., how individual driver behaviors (e.g., car-following, lane-changing) govern changes in flow, density, and speed in time and space.  Understanding these mechanisms has important implications for mobility and safety. Transitions around freeway bottlenecks can determine bottleneck throughput and hence the travel delays on freeway networks. Further, vehicles in transition regions are more prone to rear-end crashes due to sudden changes in speed and frequent lane-changing maneuvers. Finally, recurring deceleration-acceleration cycles in stop-and-go traffic can increase fuel consumption and engine emissions.

Through empirical analyses, analytical modeling, and simulations, this research made contributions in four major aspects. First, we investigated how drivers at different types of merges (with different geometry) take turns to merge in congestion and developed a model to estimate the turn-taking ratio. It was found that this ratio depends on the lane-flow distribution; i.e., how drivers distribute themselves into different freeway lanes. To make this model more practically usable, we performed an extensive empirical study to identify typical patterns of lane-flow distribution and influential factors (e.g., presence of a high-occupancy-vehicle lane) for three-lane facilities and developed a statistical model to predict the identified patterns. These efforts laid the foundation to better predict how congestion might spread around merges.

In the second aspect, this research unveiled how driver behaviors of car-following and lane-changing are linked to capacity drop and stop-and-go driving, and developed models to reproduce the mechanisms. We found that variable driver characteristics within each driver (changes in driver response time over time) has a profound reproducible impact on traffic throughput and the periodicity of stop-and-go driving. Particularly, our findings suggest that the bottleneck throughput can diminish by 8%-23% when drivers adopt larger response times in reaction to stop-and-go disturbances. Heavy vehicles were found to have a unique impact on these phenomena. Presence of heavy vehicles can reduce speed variations and alleviate stop-and-go traffic conditions through smoother car-following and reduced lane changes around them. However, large space gaps tend to persist behind heavy vehicles, which can contribute to underutilization of road capacity.  

In the third aspect, building on the better understanding of the capacity drop phenomenon, this research developed models to describe the probabilistic nature of traffic breakdown (extensive congestion that leads to capacity drop and stop-and-go conditions), and the mechanisms of capacity drop at more general, complicated bottlenecks such as spatially-extended merge, diverge and weave bottlenecks, based on driver behaviors. These models were validated with real data and provide important insights into effective traffic control strategies to improve traffic flow.

Based on the empirical investigations and modeling, we developed various traffic control strategies to mitigate traffic breakdown, capacity drop and stop-and-go conditions, thereby improving travel delay, travel reliability and safety. These strategies pertain to mainline traffic control via variable speed limits to proactively reduce the probability of traffic breakdown, maintain higher traffic throughput in the event of breakdown, and smooth congested traffic. The strategies were developed based on the current sensing and communication technologies as well as emerging technologies such as connected and automated vehicles.

In summary, the results of this research provide a better understanding of the mechanisms behind important dynamic traffic features, models to describe them, and traffic control strategies to manage traffic congestion more effectively and improve safety. The results of this research have been disseminated through publications in high impact journals and presentations at numerous conferences and academic institutions. The results have also been incorporated into one undergraduate course and two graduate courses. This research involved three PhD students and two postdocs as well as several undergraduate students. This project also involved one PhD student (Hispanic female) and one postdoc (female) from underrepresented groups.
